# Steps to reproduce
Enable scriptblock logging via GPO or registry:
Computer Configuration/Policies/Administrative Templates/Windows Components/Windows Powershell/Turn on Powershell Script Block Logging = 'Enabled'
Create a scriptblock inside of PowerShellCore 7
{"log this as verbose in PowershellCore/Operational"}

# Expected behavior
All scriptblocks are logged to PowershellCore/Operational

# Actual behavior
Only scriptblocks considered suspicious will produce a 'warning' eventID 4104

Updating the following will enable the required logging
powershell.config.json must be updated with similar settings to below:
	"PowerShellPolicies": {
		"ScriptBlockLogging": {
			"EnableScriptBlockInvocationLogging": false,
			"EnableScriptBlockLogging": true
		},
		"ModuleLogging": {
			"EnableModuleLogging": false
		},
		"ProtectedEventLogging": {
			"EnableProtectedEventLogging": false
		}		
	},
	"LogLevel": "verbose"


# Environment data
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-preview.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-preview.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.14393
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
>  scriptblocks considered suspicious will produce a 'warning' eventID 4104

It is by-design, we do not change the code from 6.0 release - EnableScriptBlockLogging logs only suspicious code.
EnableScriptBlockInvocationLogging = true will log every script block execution.

I see Windows PowerShell behaviour is different. If run "gcm gcm" Windows PowerShell writes to log but Core not. I am not sure that it is a problem.
@daxian-dbw @TravisEz13 

https://github.com/daxian-dbw/PowerShell/blob/d519e7a99a95e6d07ac3f7bc32cbbae428912e61/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/runtime/CompiledScriptBlock.cs#L1947-L1961

Thanks.  Working for me in PS7 p5 as long as the following is set to 1 
Get-ItemPropertyValue -Path HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\PowershellCore\ScriptblockLogging -Name EnableScriptBlockLogging

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @jdotmac Current logic is that PowerShell Core fallback to Windows PowerShell policy settings if the are not PowerShell Core settings.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
@iSazonov You have to explicitly say in the core policy to fallback to Window PowerShell Policy.

You should be able to log more that suspicious script blocks.
